In the DRC, Chinese and American companies race for lithium
subhead: In the southeast of the Democratic Republic of Congo, the city of Manono sits atop the world's largest reserves of this mineral essential to the energy transition. A Chinese group signed the first contract there in 2022, followed this year by a California-based company.
byline: By Guillaume Jan (Manono (Democratic Republic of Congo), special correspondent)

title: Tour de France Femmes: Le Court makes history for Africa with fifth-stage victory

Journalists in the West Bank face mounting suppression
subhead: Since October 7, Israel has arrested and imprisoned at least 140 journalists working in this occupied territory, most often under the catch-all charge of 'incitement to terrorism.' The Palestinian Journalists Syndicate has condemned what it describes as a strategy to 'silence' media professionals.
byline: By Lucas Minisini (Ramallah (West Bank) special correspondent)

title: UNICEF France calls for protecting underage victims of criminal exploitation rather than punishment
subhead: In a new report, the French branch of the UN agency highlights the lack of resources for identifying and protecting minors who are victims of criminal exploitation. It makes 75 recommendations for public authorities.

title: Léon Marchand smashes 200m medley world record
subhead: In the semifinal of the world swimming championships, the French 23-year-old beat Ryan Lochte's record from 2011 by more than one second.

title: 'I learned freedom at 34, and it was a revelation': Katja Lange-Müller, an eastern wind blows through West Berlin
subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (3/6). Katja Lange-Müller, born in the German Democratic Republic (GDR), managed as an adult to cross 'to the other side' of the Wall, escaping her mother, a prominent member of the communist regime.

title: 'In the West Berlin squats, we argued but lived together': Karin Wieland, political rebel
subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (2/6). In the late 1970s, Karin Wieland fled her small German town to live communally in an abandoned building in Kreuzberg, throwing herself into every cause of the era.

title: Nika Lozovska, chef: 'I work in a London restaurant called Brat. In Ukrainian, that means brother'
subhead: 'Refugee Recipes' (2/6). After training in Paris, Chef Nika Lozovska opened her restaurant, Dizyngoff, in the Black Sea city of Odesa in 2015. She fled the war in Ukraine and settled in London, where she keeps the memory of her hometown alive through a heirloom tomato and samphire salad.

title: Letters from prisoners held in solitary confinement: 'I feel like becoming violent again'
subhead: Le Monde asked five prisoners and a former inmate – the armed robber Rédoine Faïd, four drug traffickers, and a radicalized Islamist – to recount daily life in solitary confinement.
